braces.description: We always use $\{\}$ braces when we describe a set.
braces.question: Which of the following is a valid description of a set?

former.description: One way to describe a set is to write out all of it's elements. That is a bit hard to do if the set has an infinite number of elements. Another way to describe a set is to use a :term:`set former` like this: $\{x\ |\ x$ is a positive integer$\}$.
former.question: Choose which best describes this set.

members.description: $x \in P$ means that $x$ is a member of set $P$. $x \notin P$ means that  $x$ is not a member of set $P$
members.question: Let $P = \{a, b, c\}$, which of the following are $\notin P$?

null.description: $\emptyset$ is the symbol for the null set or the empty set. Alternatively, we might write the empty set as $\{\}$.
null.question: Which of the following is $\in \emptyset$?
answer: $\emptyset$ has no elements because it is the null set
choices: $\emptyset$ has no elements because it is the null set
correctFeedback: Note that $\{\}$ is not in $\emptyset$ because $\emptyset$ has no members, not even the empty set.

size.description: $|P|$ means size or cardinality of set $P$.
size.question: What does it mean to say that $|P| = 3$?
choices: P has an element with value 3

size2.description: $|P|$ means size or cardinality of set $P$.
size2.question: What is $|\{3, 4, 4, 5\}|$?
correctFeedback: A set has no concept of duplicate elements.

subset.description: The notation $P \subseteq Q$ or $Q \supseteq P$ both mean that set $P$ is included in set $Q$. That is, set $P$ is a subset of set $Q$ ($\subseteq$), or set $Q$ is a superset of the set $P$ ($\supseteq$).
subset.question: Let $P = \{x\ |\ x\ \mbox{is a positive integer}\}$. Which of the following is a subset of $P$?
correctFeedback: When using symbol $\subseteq$, a subset of $P$ can be equal to $P$. On the other hand, the symbol $\subset$ refers to a proper subset of $P$, meaning that the subset cannot equal $P$.

union.description: $P \cup Q$ means set union: All elements appearing in $P$ OR $Q$
union.question: Let $P = \{1, 3, 5\}$, and $Q = \{2, 4, 5, 6\}$. What is $P \cup Q$?

emptyunion.description: $P \cup Q$ means set union: All elements appearing in $P$ OR $Q$
emptyunion.question: Let $P = \{1, 3, 5\}$, and $Q = \{2, 4, 5, 6\}$. What is $Q \cup P$?
correctFeedback: Remember that sets have no concept of duplicate elements, so it doesn't matter how many times you list them, it's the same set.

commute.description: $P \cup Q$ means set union: All elements appearing in $P$ OR $Q$
commute.question: [T/F] $P \cup Q = Q \cup P$

intersect.description: $P \cap Q$ means set intersection: All elements appearing in $P$ AND $Q$
intersect.question: Let $P = \{1, 3, 5\}$, and $Q = \{2, 4, 5, 6\}$. What is $P \cap Q$?

emptyintersect.description: $P \cap Q$ means set intersection: All elements appearing in $P$ AND $Q$
emptyintersect.question: Let $P = \{1, 3, 5\}$, and $Q = \{2, 4, 6\}$. What is $P \cap Q$

commuteI.description: $P \cap Q$ means set intersection: All elements appearing in $P$ AND $Q$
commuteI.question: [T/F] $P \cap Q = Q \cap P$

setdiff.description: $P - Q$ means set difference: all elements of set $P$ NOT in set $Q$
setdiff.question: Let $P = \{1, 3, 5\}$, and $Q = \{2, 4, 5, 6\}$. What is $P - Q$?
correctFeedback: Extra elements in $Q$ (like 2, 4, and 6 in this example) do not matter. Only the 5 matters here, it is removed from $P$ in the answer.

setdiff2.description: $P - Q$ means set difference: all elements of set $P$ NOT in set $Q$
setdiff2.question: Let $P = \{1, 3, 5\}$, and $Q = \{2, 4, 5, 6\}$. What is $Q - P?$

setdiffcomm.description: $P - Q$ means set difference: all elements of set $P$ NOT in set $Q$
setdiffcomm.question: [T/F] $P - Q = Q - P$

product.description: $P \times Q$ means set (Cartesian) Product. This operation yields a set of ordered pairs.
product.question: Let $P = \{1, 3, 5\}$, and $Q = \{2, 4\}$ What is $P \times Q$? Note that if there are 3 elements in $P$ and 2 elements in $Q$, then there must be $2 \times 3 = 6$ elements in $P \times Q$.

productsize.description: $P \times Q$ means set (Cartesian) Product. This operation yields a set of ordered pairs.
productsize.question: For $P = \{1, 3, 5\}$, and $Q = \{2, 4\}$, what is $|P \times Q|$?

powerset.description: The powerset of set $S$ (written $2^S$ ) is the set of all possible subsets for $S$
powerset.question: For set $S = \{a, b, c\}$, what is $2^S$?

powersize.description: The powerset of set $S$ (written $2^S$ ) is the set of all possible subsets for $S$
powersize.question: For set $S = \{a, b, c\}$, what is $|2^S|$?
correctFeedback: If $|S| = n$, then $|2^S| = 2^n$. Which helps to explain why this notation is used.
